item.title: Permanent Conversion Timing Optimal: When to Convert Construction Loan to Permanent Mortgage
item.description:
One of the biggest advantages of construction-to-permanent loans is the seamless conversion from construction financing to permanent mortgage when your home is complete—no second application, no additional closing costs, no refinancing hassle. But this automatic conversion only happens when specific conditions are met, timing is critical, and understanding how the conversion process works prevents surprises that could delay your move-in or increase your costs.

If you’re financing new construction, understanding permanent conversion timing helps you coordinate with your builder, protect your rate lock, and ensure the transition from interest-only construction payments to principal-and-interest permanent payments happens smoothly when your home is ready for occupancy.

item.title: Construction-to-Permanent Loan Guide: Complete Process from Groundbreaking to Permanent Mortgage
item.description:
Building your dream home from the ground up is exciting—but the financing can feel overwhelming if you don’t understand how construction-to-permanent loans actually work. Unlike traditional mortgages where you borrow once and start making payments immediately, construction-to-permanent financing structures everything differently: one closing, extended rate locks, draw-based funding, interest-only payments during the build, and automatic conversion to a traditional mortgage when construction is complete.

If you’re considering new construction, understanding this loan type is essential before signing builder contracts or breaking ground. Here’s everything you need to know about construction-to-permanent loans—from qualification through final conversion.
